body:
## test(treesitter): add test cases for inspect_tree

Based on @altermo's work #26944, but modified to use `eq` instead of `Screen:expect` because it's difficult to write tests and debug.

## feat(treesitter): use 0-based indexing to show ranges in `:InspectTree`

Problem:

- `:InspectTree` was showing node ranges in 1-based indexing, i.e., in
  vim cursor position (lnum, col). However, treesitter API adopts
  0-based indexing to represent ranges (Range4). This can often be
  confusing for developers and plugin authors when debugging code
  written with treesiter APIs.

Solution:

- Change to 0-based indexing from 1-based indexing to show node ranges
  in `:InspectTree`.

- Note: To make things not complicated, we do not provide an option or
  keymap to configure which indexing mode to use.


## Status

~~Will wait until #26944 is merged first, after which I can rebase again and add test cases for #26944 and #27336 together.~~

comment_regular_data.body:
Things to discuss:

- The keymap -- `R` or `r`? (which stands for *R*ange) (Note: #26944 may want to use a similar key for *R*oot).
- Do we want to make this by default? Was there any reason we chose to show 1-based lnum/col instead of `Range4`, when it was first introduced 0.9.0, given that its earlier form (TSPlayground) showed 0-based ranges?

What is the actual issue here? This is a visual diagnostic tool for humans, and humans -- like Vim -- tend to count from one. 

I don't think we need to burn a key for subtracting one from some numbers... (I know people complain about the younger generations' lack of math skills, but we are not quite _there_ yet.)

I agree that 1-based ranges should be the default representation to display for human, when dealing with `TSNode`s printed or `vim.inspect`-ed while writing treesitter-related plugins, debugging, writing tests (e.g. [`parser_spec.lua`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/v0.9.5/test/functional/treesitter/parser_spec.lua#L217)) it can be confusing in another way, when it comes to treesitter dev. Because the primary representation of Range is 0-based.

It could be just a matter of straightforward off-by-one index calculation, but it brings just slightly additional mental effort.

If we want to avoid reserving a key for this, I'm also fine with just having it enabled only through API, i.e. `opts` to `vim.treesitter.inspect_tree()`. Or only providing an API (function that users can call if they want), not assigning a default key. Anyway such an option will be needed.

> What is the actual issue here? This is a visual diagnostic tool for humans, and humans -- like Vim -- tend to count from one.
> 
> I don't think we need to burn a key for subtracting one from some numbers... (I know people complain about the younger generations' lack of math skills, but we are not quite _there_ yet.)

I feel like this is a valid ask. Reducing the math conversions when using the visualizer makes it a nicer dev tool.

This does not need to be an option, certainly not a key binding. If we are going to change anything we can make the default 0-indexed (which I’m fine with), but making this configurable introduces more complexity for very little gain.
The additional tests are welcome and appreciated regardless though.
I agree, options make this more complicated than it should be for something that is community maintained. Make it either 0-based, or 1-based.

Thanks for the inputs. I agree with not providing configurable/toggleable options.

My proposal is to change `:InspectTree` to be always 0-based,  because of the following reasons:

- `:InspectTree` is mostly used for debugging treesitter syntax tree, e.g. when writing queries or do something with the treesitter API.
- In such cases, developers would need to deal with mostly `TSNode:range()` and `vim.api.*` APIs for buffer manipulation, etc., which are all using 0-based indexing.
- Therefore, representing the tree/node range in 0-based index would be less confusing, and it would require less mental effort and save just one additional calculation step while debugging.
- `:InspectTree` would synchronize with the source buffer, whose 1-based line number can be easily read from the window in which the buffer is contained.
- [The upstream tree-sitter playground](https://tree-sitter.github.io/tree-sitter/playground) also shows node ranges in 0-based indexing. Hence more consistency.

Note: `vim.treesitter.{inspect_tree,show_tree}` was first written in #21322.
